item.title: 10 Biggest Traditions In The Legend of Zelda Series
item.description:
Summary

  • Link, Zelda, and Ganondorf are reincarnations, with each game being a new chapter in their endless cycle haunted by Demise's curse
  • Dungeons are a significant tradition in Zelda games, challenging players with distinct and unique themes in each one.
  • The Master Sword and Hylian Shield are iconic equipment for Link, with heart containers representing his progression as he collects them.

Shigeru Miyamoto, besides being one of the minds behind the creation of Mario , was also responsible for conceiving The Legend of Zelda , one of the best franchises ever produced by Nintendo. In this epic Action-Adventure, players generally control Link on a journey to save the Kingdom of Hyrule from the forces of evil, with many gameplay elements influencing the development of other games.

Additionally, throughout all these games, several details have been marked by their presence in most releases, becoming the biggest traditions of The Legend of Zelda titles , whether through core gameplay mechanics or even some narrative references. Thus, whenever a new game is announced, fans can expect most of these elements to be present in Link’s journey.

10 Broken Pots

Link Can Cause Havoc By Entering A House And Smashing Its Pots

A lighter tradition of The Legend of Zelda , yet still present in most games, is that Link often has to smash pots wherever possible, whether to gather a few rupees for buying a new item or to look for hearts to replenish health. In several titles, it is even possible to barge into an NPC’s house in search of pots to break.

This tradition is so significant in the series that certain games, such as Ocarina of Time , include lines from NPCs commenting on Link’s habit of breaking pots or even encouraging the character to do so. Thus, it remains a minor gameplay element but appears in the great majority of the franchise’s titles.

9 Dungeons

This Gameplay Segment Is One Of The Biggest Traditions Of The Legend Of Zelda

Ever since it was conceived on the NES, one of the greatest traditions always present in The Legend of Zelda has been the dungeons, challenges placed in Link’s path to prove his power and worth as a hero. Even if a game features many of them, each one is built with a distinct and unique theme.

Although the more recent Nintendo Switch titles have somewhat set this aspect aside, choosing simpler and not-so-complex challenges, there are still several dungeons in The Legend of Zelda that are iconic to the franchise. Hence, with each new installment in the series, fans look forward to seeing how the developer will use creativity to challenge the hero on his journey.

8 Master Sword And The Hylian Shield

They Are The Two Most Iconic Pieces Of Equipment For Link In The Games

While the character can wield different weapons during the adventure, bows, boomerangs, and bombs, the most recognizable gear for Link are the Master Sword and the Hylian Shield. In most official artwork, the character is shown with these two items, which have become part of his look, even though the shield does not appear in every game.

However, the Master Sword is nearly a trademark of the franchise, and the moment Link first discovers this blade is one of the most iconic scenes in each title, besides being one of the biggest traditions of The Legend of Zelda . The epic tone of these moments, combined with each title’s context - such as in Breath of the Wild - makes everything more striking.

7 A Silent Hero

Link Is Not Someone Of Many Words

Silent protagonists are a tradition in many games, and Link, in The Legend of Zelda , is another character who fits this pattern. Throughout his appearances in mainline games, spinoffs, or even special cameos in other titles, he was never particularly vocal. Nonetheless, in games like Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom , it is possible to select some dialogue options that shed light on the character’s personality.

However, even if these dialogue choices exist, Link does not have any actual lines, only groans and shouts when fighting enemies. On the other hand, Nintendo compensated for his silence by making him very expressive, which reveals more about his nature without requiring him to speak.

6 Music

Whether As A Mechanic Or A Soundtrack, It Is A Strong Element In The Zelda Games

One of the biggest traditions in The Legend of Zelda has always been the attention given to each game’s soundtrack, resulting in many iconic songs throughout the franchise. The main theme, for instance, is only one among several standout melodies in the series, showcasing the epic tone of every adventure.

Yet this tradition is not tied solely to soundtrack quality, because in many of Link’s reincarnations, the character also demonstrated skill with various musical instruments. In several games, such as Ocarina of Time or Wind Waker , music served as a core mechanic, enabling the character to perform different melodies and progress in the game.

5 Strong Focus On Exploration

The Legend Of Zelda Games Has Always Provided A Lot Of Freedom To Players

Although some games in the franchise feature a more linear progression, one of the greatest traditions in The Legend of Zelda has always involved the freedom players have in exploring. The environments usually encourage this with their design, especially dungeons, concealing secrets and other items in various locations to discover during gameplay.

However, Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom elevated the concept of exploration to a whole new level in the franchise, creating vast open worlds for players to explore at will. Both games implemented a successful non-linear approach to the map, with a design that sparks curiosity about different areas of the world.

4 Heart Containers

They Represent The Character’s Progression

The Legend of Zelda never used a level-based progression system or a skill tree to convey how Link evolves, so a way to represent that, apart from the new equipment he obtains, has always been through Heart Containers. These items are found in dungeons or during map exploration and, over time, expand the protagonist’s health points.

This has also been one of the biggest traditions of the franchise, present in practically every mainline entry. Although Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom slightly changed this formula, the logic for boosting both HP and Stamina remains similar, requiring the character to collect Spirit Orbs and later exchange them at Goddess Statues dotted around the map.

3 Epic Boss Battles

Many Of These Encounters Are Memorable In The Legend Of Zelda

In addition to the other challenges Link faces in his journey, the adventure would not exist without battles against varied bosses. Many of these fights are remembered by players as some of the best in The Legend of Zelda , whether for the enemy’s difficulty or the unique mechanics and design.

Moreover, Nintendo has consistently presented these clashes in an epic manner, whether through the soundtrack or the buildup to these bosses, creating a clear difference between them and regular enemies. This approach is why clashes against Ghirahim, Koloktos, or even Colgera in Tears of the Kingdom resonate so strongly with players.

2 The Triforce

It Is Part Of The Mythology Of Hyrule And A Franchise Tradition

Just as Link, Zelda, and Ganondorf are fated to meet, another aspect of the series’ mythology that appears in nearly every The Legend of Zelda installment is the Triforce. This artifact symbolizes balance in the world and frequently drives the conflicts in the games, as villains strive to claim it for total control.

The Triforce has a simple yet iconic design and is used as one of The Legend of Zelda ’s main logos, appearing on many covers. Furthermore, the fact that it can only be fully obtained by Link in some games adds to the mystique surrounding this item.

1 The Characters Are Reincarnations

Link, Zelda, And Ganondorf Are Variations Of The Same Character

Even though Link, Zelda, and, most of the time, Ganondorf are recurring characters and one of the biggest traditions of The Legend of Zelda , they almost never are the same individuals from previous games. That is because in Skyward Sword , the title that begins the entire series timeline, it is explained that Demise, the villain, casts a curse so his hatred would remain with them forever.

So each game is a new chapter in this endless cycle, where descendants of the princess Zelda and those who carry Link’s heroic spirit remain haunted by Demise’s curse, which manifests as Ganondorf. Even if in one game or another certain facts are altered, players generally follow the story of these destinies clashing in the game.

item.title: Marvel Rivals Announces a New Skin for Human Torch
item.description:
Summary

  • Human Torch is joining Marvel Rivals as a Duelist with fire attacks and team-ups.
  • Negative Zone Gladiator costume for Human Torch will be priced at 1,600 Units, according to leaks.
  • The update will also bring The Thing as a Vanguard hero, new map, challenges, and balance changes.

Marvel Rivals has announced that Human Torch will be making his debut alongside the Negative Zone Gladiator costume. NetEase Games is about to launch a major mid-season update for Marvel Rivals , which will introduce a wealth of new content to the popular hero shooter. Fans can expect to see two new heroes, a Central Park map, numerous balance changes, and new challenges with free rewards.

It has been revealed that Human Torch will be a Duelist in Marvel Rivals , which means he'll be taking the fight to the enemy team head-on. As a flying hero, he has the ability to hurl flames at his foes from high in the air, but he also an ability that sends him crashing down with a fiery strike. He can even create walls of fire that deal damage to all nearby enemies, allowing him to create zones that could prove deadly for anyone caught inside. His ultimate ability transforms his usual primary flame attack into fire tornadoes. When Storm is present as an ally, she can use her ult to take over one of the tornadoes, combining it with her own to devastating effect. Johnny also has a team-up with Invisible Woman, which gives him extra shields to protect him from incoming attacks.

In a recent post on Twitter, NetEase Games revealed that the Negative Zone Gladiator costume will arrive in the shop at the same time as Human Torch in Marvel Rivals . The new outfit paints the jovial Johnny Storm in a darker light, as he is covered in black armor with bits of flame managing to shine through. A knotted dark material appears to have crawled up his arm and on the side of his face, giving the clean-cut hero a grizzled look. The outfit also lacks any symbol that would mark him as a member of The Fantastic Four, which is unusual for the fiery youngster.

Marvel Rivals Reveals Negative Zone Gladiator Costume

According to leakers, the skin's bundle will be priced at 1,600 Units in Marvel Rivals , which means it will be considered an epic rarity cosmetic. NetEase Games recently announced that players who earn extra Chrono Tokens over the course of the season will soon be able to trade them in for Units, allowing fans to claim more items in the shop for free.

Human Torch won't be arriving alone, as gamers will also be able to play The Thing in Marvel Rivals when the massive update launches on February 21. The stony hero will be the title's newest Vanguard, with an ability kit that allows him to charge straight into battle. The Thing focuses on pummeling his opponents and even has a passive ability that prevents him from being moved or manipulated by incoming attacks. With so much content releasing soon and even more planned for the future, many fans are looking forward to seeing what NetEase Games does next.

item.title: Stories from Sol: The Gun-Dog - Official Launch Trailer
item.description: Don't miss the official launch trailer for Stories from Sol: The Gun-Dog, a retro visual novel and graphic adventure from Space Colony Studios.

item.title: 18 Easy Platinum Trophies To Get On PS4
item.description:
Everyone with a PlayStation 4 (or PS5) knows that the way to level up their account is by gaining trophies. Certain games can be completed while players barely earn a single trophy; in other titles, most are unmissable. Some games make their trophies extremely hard to get, but one thing is for certain — if someone does manage to grab every bronze, silver, and gold trophy that a game has to offer, they'll be given the coveted Platinum trophy, which will advance their level the most.

Some people consider themselves trophy hunters and pride themselves on their literally thousands of achievements. Some people don't care. But if a player would like some Platinum trophies on their accounts and are struggling to get them, here are some games that'll make it really easy (along with some that are fairly easy and still extremely enjoyable).

Updated February 20, 2025 by Mark Sammut: More specifications have been added for the PS4 games with the easiest Platinum trophies , along with updated percentages for the PSNProfiles completion rates. Furthermore, a new puzzle game has been introduced as a recommendation.

Completion time is based on HowLongToBeat or TrueTrophies. For the percentage of people who unlocked the Platinum, PSNProfiles was used as a resource.

18 The Gardens Between

Average Completionist Time: 3 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 18
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 27.3%

Available for both the PS5 and PS4, The Gardens Between is a delightful puzzle game that focuses just as much on the atmosphere as it does on providing a challenging experience. That said, the puzzles are generally well done and fun to complete, even if they might not necessarily be the hardest in the genre.

The game can be readily completed within about three hours, and it is possible to get the PS4 Platinum trophy within that time. Most of the trophies are just unlocked naturally while playing through the campaign, to the point that most of them are harder to miss than collect. Most importantly, The Gardens Between is just charming, both in terms of tone and presentation.

17 Any Telltale Game (The Wolf Among Us, As An Example)

Average Completionist Time: 11 Hours (The Wolf Among Us)

  • Number of Trophies: 36
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 19.1%

Telltale's resume is generally a safe bet when it comes to easy PS4 Platinum trophies , as they typically do not require much effort beyond completing their campaigns and then revisiting certain chapters to pick choices that were originally skipped over. Now, the games do require around 8–10 hours to complete, so they are not especially quick sits; however, these titles can easily be platinumed within a weekend, and they are also quite enjoyable.

Besides The Wolf Among Us , Telltale's Batman seasons, The Walking Dead , Tales from the Borderlands , and Guardians of the Galaxy follow roughly the same format.

16 Burly Men At Sea

Average Completionist Time: 2.5 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 25
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 19%

A game set in Scandinavia, Burly Men at Sea is a cute little adventure game about some fishermen who come up against a bunch of mythological creatures. Players make choices that shape the entire story, much like other games, but the graphics are very simple and yet charming.

Like Telltale's games, the trophies are very easy to gain and hard to miss, so it's a good one to play through if someone is looking for some Platinums.

15 Donut County

Average Completionist Time: 2.5 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 21
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 29.7%

Donut County is an indie game with a really simple concept. The player controls a hole, which grows in size as you move it around to swallow objects.

Admittedly, the story isn't super compelling. But if someone wants a game that's a little mindless and that they don't need to pay too much attention to, along with being awarded a nice Platinum trophy at the very end of it all, this is a good one to go for. And it's admittedly very pretty.

14 My Name Is Mayo

Average Completionist Time: 1 Hour

  • Number of Trophies: 51
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 76.3%

This is purely a clicker game so, like the one above, My Name Is Mayo is a title that won't take players very long to finish. In fact, most people pick up this game purely for the trophy. Still, if someone wants some brain stimulation that won't require too much effort on their part, this is another good one to go for.

The sequels, My Name is Mayo 2 and 3 , are more of the same, delivering a blend of meta humor and quick journeys to easy Platinum trophies .

13 Until Dawn

Average Completionist Time: 19 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 19
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 2.7%

Until Dawn is much longer than most of the games on this list, but it is a title that people should find pretty easy to get invested in. The only trophy that's challenging is the one for keeping everyone alive. A horror story about a cabin in the mountains attacked by something, this group of friends has to survive... until dawn. The goal is to keep everyone alive, and there are various trophies unlocked for preserving the lives of certain people (such as all the women, all the men, etc.), and even one for killing everyone.

As long as players make sure to explore every area to find all the clues, this Platinum trophy is pretty easy to get. Why? Because when a player has done the game once, they can replay each chapter rather than having to go through the whole thing again.

12 Lara Croft & Hitman GO

Average Completionist Time: 7 Hours (Lara Croft GO & Hitman GO)

  • Number of Trophies: 18 ( Lara Croft GO ); 17 ( Hitman GO )
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 47.6% ( Lara Croft GO ); 40.4% ( Hitman GO )

A couple of turn-based puzzle games, Lara Croft GO and Hitman GO were originally released on mobile before later being ported to the PS4. Along with being pretty decent games, these two are also prime options for Platinum trophy hunters. If someone struggles with any aspect of these, it's easy to cheat and look up a walkthrough, which makes the Platinum trophy almost ridiculously easy to get.

11 Life Is Strange

Average Completionist Time: 19 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 61
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 6.7 %

Life is Strange is a pretty long game since it goes by seasons and chapters. However, much like Until Dawn, it's easy to get the trophies because players don't have to go super out of their way for any and none are particularly difficult.

The concept of the game is rewinding time and making different choices to affect the present and future. In itself, this is a pretty fascinating mechanic, and Life is Strange is one of those games that people can get utterly lost in. Players will have the Platinum before they know it, although it cannot generally be achieved in just one playthrough.

10 Theme Park Simulator

Average Completionist Time: 2 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 12
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 26.5%

Theme Park Simulator sounds a lot more fun than it actually is. Those expecting a Rollercoaster Tycoon type of experience will be left bitterly disappointed. Those looking for an easy Platinum trophy ; however, have definitely come to the right theme park.

In order to unlock the game's Platinum trophy, players will need to watch each of the park's attractions for five minutes. This basically entails doing absolutely nothing. It's possible to play around with the camera and change the time of day, but most will likely set their controller down and do something else until five minutes have passed. There are 11 attractions in total, so with setup time, it'll take around 1 hour for the Platinum to pop.

9 Round Invaders

Average Completionist Time: 1 Hour

  • Number of Trophies: 13
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 97.8%

Boasting one of the highest completion rates on PSNProfiles, Round Invaders is the type of game that seemingly exists specifically to boost somebody's Platinum trophy count. The PlayStation Store has plenty of cheap titles that require only the bare minimum to unlock all their trophies, and Round Invaders serves as a prime example of such a release.

An arcade shooter that encircles players with enemies, Round Invaders delivers the exact experience advertised by its title. Just play the game for an hour and, more often than not, the Platinum will be rewarded.

The other Round Invaders games are also easy Platinum trophies.

8 Brotherhood United

Average Completionist Time: 2 Hours

  • Number of Trophies: 18
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 75.03%

Brotherhood United is one of the easiest Platinum trophies available on PSN . Unlocking all the trophies will take players somewhere between 30 and 40 minutes. While it's not quite a walk in the park in terms of difficulty, it's certainly not going to trouble too many players either.

To obtain all the trophies, players just have to play through the game until certain cumulative targets have been met. These include killing a certain number of enemies, saving a certain number of hostages, and things like that. There are a few specific trophies like completing a stage without dying or using grenades, but these aren't too difficult to accomplish after a bit of practice.

7 112th Seed

Average Completionist Time: 1 Hour

  • Number of Trophies: 14
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 82%

Once in a while, it is not to just complete something simple. 112th Seed doesn't complicate matters for trophy hunters; looking to earn the Platinum? Then just complete the first 30 levels. It is that straightforward.

As an added bonus, 112th Seed also happens to be a pretty fun 2D puzzle platformer. As the titular seed, players must sprout plants that can serve as platforms and make their way through quick but rather engaging levels. There are much worse ways to spend an hour.

6 Pretty Girls Breakers!

Average Completionist Time: N/A

  • Number of Trophies: 16
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 77%

Released on March 3, 2022, Pretty Girls Breakers! is an arcade block-breaker title featuring more than 20 stages. Nearly everyone has played this style of game at one point or another, and for trophy hunters who find these titles relaxing, Pretty Girls Breakers! is a decent option that should also net them a Platinum quite quickly.

The trophies are very straightforward: simply clear the first three stages of five characters (Aoi, Nazuna, Sumire, Tsubaki, and Sherira). Once those are unlocked, the Platinum will follow.

5 A Day Without Me

Average Completionist Time: 1 Hour

  • Number of Trophies: 12
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 77.3%

A short puzzle horror game by Gamecom Team, A Day Without Me drops players into a deserted town and tells them to investigate. Nuggets of information are presented throughout the campaign, although the story can be somewhat difficult to piece together.

Overall, A Day Without Me shouldn't take more than an hour or two to complete, and getting the Platinum generally just requires completing the story. The puzzles are also quite easy, so the game should not provide too much challenge beyond the occasional unclear objective.

4 Little Adventure On The Prairie

Average Completionist Time: 40 Minutes

  • Number of Trophies: 22
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 88.8%

Another game seemingly designed for trophy hunters, Little Adventure on the Prairie has nothing to offer beyond a small serotonin boost when its Platinum unlocks. The game is a 2D action side-scroller, although it does not offer much in the way of challenge beyond the typical frustration that comes with playing this sort of experience.

The trophies are unlocked naturally by completing the game. The majority of them are tied to finishing levels, although there are a few associated with power-ups. The only reason this game is even remotely worth mentioning is due to its short runtime, but it will not be a particularly gratifying Platinum.

3 Road Bustle

Average Completionist Time: 23 Minutes

  • Number of Trophies: 17
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 85.5%

Sticking with the theme of indie releases that gift Platinums, Road Bustle is a score-based title that tasks players with crossing roads whole avoid traffic. Acquire enough points, and the Platinum will be unlocked. Despite featuring literal roadblocks, Road Bustle provides little in the way of resistance since its drivers seem to be relatively wary of the roads.

This game essentially offers a way to purchase a Platinum trophy for roughly a dollar. And, the same can be said for the developer's other PS4 releases like Funny Truck and Space Intervention ​​.

2 Storm Boy

Average Completionist Time: 32 Minutes

  • Number of Trophies: 12
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 88.3%

Storm Boy is a very basic collection of minigames based on a children's book of the same name from the 1960s. Despite its low price, it's actually a decent game. In fact, some will likely find its visuals to be charming. Maybe. It certainly seems like a lot of love went into making the game although perhaps not quite as much time. On the subject of time, those looking for an easy Platinum can expect to spend 30 minutes or so playing Storm Boy .

First, players will need to play each of the game's minigames. It's possible to get the trophy by quitting as soon as the criteria have been met, but they're so short there's almost no point. After playing every game at least once, they'll then need to be played a second time through the 'remember' submenu accessed from the game's main menu. Once again, quitting out after a few seconds won't prevent the Platinum trophy from popping so the option remains for anybody just wanting to get their trophy and move on.

1 FoxyLand

Average Completionist Time: 1 Hour

  • Number of Trophies: 15
  • Percentage Of PlayStation Players With Platinum Trophy: 75.9%

FoxyLand was released towards the end of 2019 and seems to exist primarily to provide a quick and easy Platinum trophy. There's very little skill required in order to unlock all the game's trophies, and it can be accomplished in around 20 minutes.

Looking at the trophy requirements may make the prospect of obtaining the Platinum seem more daunting than it actually is. Except for the one obtained by purchasing an item from the game's shop though, all the trophies will pop at some point during a playthrough. FoxyLand is an incredibly short and easy game and players don't actually need to reach the very end in order for the Platinum trophy to pop. FoxyLand 2 follows the same formula.

item.title: Xbox Game Pass Ultimate Adds 2 More Games for February 2025
item.description:
Summary

  • Xbox Game Pass has added Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader on February 20.
  • EA Sports F1 24 will join the PC Game Pass and XGP Ultimate libraries later today.
  • Only one more title is confirmed to be coming to Microsoft's subscription service before the end of February 2025.

Xbox Game Pass Ultimate members can start playing Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader and EA Sports F1 24 as part of their subscription starting today, February 20. These additions bring the total number of 2025 Xbox Game Pass Ultimate releases to 19.

February 2025 is shaping up to be a relatively slow month for Microsoft's subscription service, with its release cadence cut in half compared to January. On the other hand, this month's lineup is fairly diverse, bolstering the Xbox Game Pass selection of RPGs, shooters, action adventures, strategies, and sports games.

Continuing this trend, EA Sports F1 24 and Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader are expanding Microsoft's content catalog on February 20. Rogue Trader reached the subscription service in the early morning (ET), whereas EA Sports' racing sim is set to follow in the coming hours. EA Play titles are typically added to Xbox Game Pass later in the day, so it's no surprise that Rogue Trader arrived before F1 24 .

Made by Cyprus-based Owlcat Games, Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader is a classic CRPG that offers turn-based combat, branching quests with meaningful choices, and a lengthy story that takes over 60 hours to complete—even without engaging in side content. The game was released in December 2023 to a largely positive reception, as underlined by its "Strong" rating on OpenCritic, derived from an average score of 78 and a 77% reviewer recommendation rate.

F1 24 is a more mainstream addition to the Xbox Game Pass Ultimate library, not least because it's the latest entry in Codemasters' popular series of Formula One sims. It also boasts a "Strong" OpenCritic rating, with a 77 average score and a 60% recommendation rate. Since it's part of the EA Play catalog, F1 24 is only accessible to Microsoft's subscribers paying for PC Game Pass or Xbox Game Pass Ultimate. Meanwhile, Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader can also be played via the Standard-tier membership.

Upcoming Xbox Game Pass Games

Game

Date Added

Game Pass Tier(s)

Platform(s)

Notes

EA Sports F1 24

Feb 20

Ultimate, PC

Cloud, Console, PC

Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader

Feb 20

Watch Dogs: Legion

Feb 25

Ultimate, PC, Standard

Cloud, Console, PC

Atomfall

Mar 27

Ultimate, PC

South of Midnight

Apr 8

Ultimate, PC

Day-one release.

Commandos: Origins

Apr 9

Ultimate, PC

Cloud, Console, PC

Day-one release.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33

Apr 24

Ultimate, PC

PC, Series X/S

Day-one release.

DOOM: The Dark Ages

May 15

Ultimate, PC

PC, Series X/S

Day-one release.

Xbox Game Pass only has one more confirmed title for February 2025. That would be Watch Dogs: Legion , which is scheduled to reach the service on Tuesday, February 25. Microsoft is then expected to announce its next wave of releases on or around March 4. Before that happens, February 28 will see Xbox Game Pass lose nine titles, including F1 22 , Gris , and Wo Long: Fallen Dynasty . The remasters of Yakuza 3 and Yakuza 4 are also leaving Microsoft's content library on that date, as are Maneater and Space Engineers .
